messageBody:
> "My 1/50 of a unit of United States Federally-Issued currency. :-)"
Which unit? :)

Seriously though, I agree with Simon. However, if this state is
necessary to be known to other objects I would suggest that the
initialize not be in the constructor. If other objects must know about
it's state, it's better to have those objects call the initialize()
themselves. On the other hand, I don't think the internal state of an
object should be publicized, as a general rule. So that might suggest
that you provide better exception handling instead (or in addition to)
the "newing" of an object.

-jason

Subject: RE: [junit] Testing initial conditions


There is a school of thought that an object's API should never allow
it's internal state to be made unstable/invalid/partially-updated. I
would vote for doing whatever it takes to ensure that the initial state
is valid and then use unit tests to ensure that it stays that way.

My 1/50 of a unit of United States Federally-Issued currency. :-)

Simon
